SubTopics: A clear thesis or position based on logical reasons supported by precise and relevant evidence.
Content: Tracy's paper needs a stronger position statement. Which of the following could best replace sentence 5 and more effectively state the position Tracy is taking in this paper?

A.Choice: In other words, the electric car is not what you should buy today, and that is my definitive opinion.

B.Choice: Truthfully, electric cars have advantages that must be pondered before making a purchase.

C.Choice: Therefore, the electric car is the wrong choice if you are currently in the market for a new car.

D.Choice: However, buying an electric car is always an option when you are thinking about a new car.

SubTopics: Revise drafts to improve style, word choice, figurative language, sentence variety, and subtlety of meaning after rethinking how well questions of purpose, audience, and genre have been addressed.
Content: Tracy has used an ineffective transition in sentence 10. Which word or phrase could best replace In the end in this sentence?

F.Choice: Obviously

G.Choice: In fact

H.Choice: However

J.Choice: Instead

SubTopics: Revise drafts to improve style, word choice, figurative language, sentence variety, and subtlety of meaning after rethinking how well questions of purpose, audience, and genre have been addressed.
Content: What is the most effective way to combine sentences 15 and 16?

A.Choice: Furthermore, the batteries in an electric car weaken over time, eventually allowing a person to travel even fewer miles between charges.

B.Choice: Furthermore, the batteries in an electric car weaken over time, eventually they allow a person to travel even fewer miles between charges.

C.Choice: Furthermore, the batteries in an electric car weaken over time, which means the batteries eventually allow a person to travel even fewer miles between charges.

D.Choice: Furthermore, the batteries in an electric car weaken over time because they eventually allow a person to travel even fewer miles between charges.

SubTopics: An organizing structure appropriate to the purpose, audience, and context.
Content: Tracy would like to add the following detail to the fourth paragraph (sentences 13–17).
:box:This makes traveling longer distances in an electric car quite inconvenient.
Where should this sentence be inserted?

F.Choice: After sentence 13

G.Choice: After sentence 14

H.Choice: After sentence 17

J.Choice: Tracy should not add this detail to the fourth paragraph.

SubTopics: Revise drafts to improve style, word choice, figurative language, sentence variety, and subtlety of meaning after rethinking how well questions of purpose, audience, and genre have been addressed.
Content: Tracy has included a redundant sentence in the last paragraph (sentences 18–23). Which sentence should be deleted from this paragraph?

A.Choice: Sentence 18

B.Choice: Sentence 19

C.Choice: Sentence 20

D.Choice: Sentence 21

SubTopics: Write an [analytical] essay of sufficient length.
Content: Fatima realizes she has offered a weak thesis in this paper. Which of the following could replace sentences 1 and 2 and provide a more effective thesis statement for Fatima's paper?

F.Choice: Mia Hamm is an interesting and fun personality, and I am grateful for this opportunity to research her story. I think that as you read my paper, you will agree that she has added great energy to women's sports in this country and also to sports around the world.

G.Choice: Mia Hamm is one of the most celebrated female soccer players of all time and is an inspiration to young women everywhere. Her contributions to women's soccer have had an unmistakable impact on the sport, both in the United States and internationally.

H.Choice: There is a soccer player in this country that is clearly more talented than all the rest. Her name is Mia Hamm, and she is an outstanding player and a model athlete who works hard to make sure she is always setting an example for other athletes and for the world at large.

J.Choice: If you don't know Mia Hamm, you probably don't know much. Many people say that she is the greatest soccer player of all time because she is so supremely committed to soccer and also to all that it means to herself and the other people of the world.

SubTopics: Revise drafts to improve style, word choice, figurative language, sentence variety, and subtlety of meaning after rethinking how well questions of purpose, audience, and genre have been addressed.
Content: What is the most effective revision to make in sentence 14?

A.Choice: And at the age of 17, she was playing for the University of North Carolina, she helped her team win four NCAA championships and broke many school records along the way.

B.Choice: And at the age of 17, she was playing for the University of North Carolina and won four NCAA championships and breaking many school records along the way, which helped her team.

C.Choice: And at the age of 17, she was playing for the University of North Carolina, which helped her team win four NCAA championships and breaking many school records along the way.

D.Choice: And at the age of 17, she was playing for the University of North Carolina, where she helped her team win four NCAA championships and broke many school records along the way.

SubTopics: Write an [analytical] essay of sufficient length.
Content: Which of these details could best follow and support sentence 22?

F.Choice: Though she had injured her ankle badly in the game, Hamm still managed to take control of the ball and pass it to a teammate who then scored the winning goal.

G.Choice: Hamm held a record for the most international goals until June 2013, when her record was broken by another American, Abby Wambach.

H.Choice: For 17 years Hamm played with and often led the U.S. Women's National Soccer Team, and she was U.S. Soccer's Female Athlete of the Year from 1994 to 1998.

J.Choice: Hamm received another great accolade in 2004, when she was included on a list of the 125 Greatest Living Soccer Players.

SubTopics: Revise drafts to improve style, word choice, figurative language, sentence variety, and subtlety of meaning after rethinking how well questions of purpose, audience, and genre have been addressed.
Content: The meaning of sentence 24 is unclear. The clarity of this sentence can be improved by changing They to  —

A.Choice: Some advertisements

B.Choice: Various women

C.Choice: Sports companies

D.Choice: International faces

SubTopics: Edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling.
Content: What change, if any, should be made in sentence 2?

F.Choice: Change hardly to really

G.Choice: Delete so

H.Choice: Insert a comma after plants

J.Choice: No change should be made in this sentence.

SubTopics: Spell correctly, including using various resources to determine and check correct spellings.
Content: How should sentence 5 be changed?

A.Choice: Change came to comes

B.Choice: Change existense to existence

C.Choice: Change the question mark to an exclamation point

D.Choice: Sentence 5 should not be changed.

SubTopics: Use a variety of correctly structured sentences (e.g., compound, complex, compound-complex).
Content: What is the correct way to write sentences 23 and 24?

F.Choice: Many of the species that once made their home on Madagascar are now extinct, scientists, however, are still making discoveries.

G.Choice: Although many of the species that once made their home on Madagascar are now extinct and scientists are still making discoveries.

H.Choice: Many of the species that once made their home on Madagascar are now extinct, but there are scientists. Who are still making discoveries.

J.Choice: Although many of the species that once made their home on Madagascar are now extinct, scientists are still making discoveries.

SubTopics: Use conventions of capitalization.
Content: What change, if any, should be made in sentence 30?

A.Choice: Change deserves to deserved

B.Choice: Delete the comma

C.Choice: Change Oasis to oasis

D.Choice: No change should be made in sentence 30.

SubTopics: Edit drafts for grammar, mechanics, and spelling.
Content: What change, if any, should be made in sentence 2?

F.Choice: Change environment to enviroment

G.Choice: Delete the comma

H.Choice: Change your to you're

J.Choice: No change should be made in this sentence.

SubTopics: Use correct punctuation marks.
Content: What change should be made in sentence 13?

A.Choice: Delete where

B.Choice: Insert a comma after class

C.Choice: Change a lot to alot

D.Choice: Change means to had meant

F.Choice: Change experiences to experience's

G.Choice: Change will help to helped

H.Choice: Change acomplished to accomplished

J.Choice: Sentence 15 should not be changed.

Content: What change should be made in sentence 22?

A.Choice: Insert a comma after day after day

B.Choice: Change that to this

C.Choice: Change am to was

D.Choice: No change should be made in sentence 22.

SubTopics: Use a variety of correctly structured sentences (e.g., compound, complex, compound-complex).
Content: What is the correct way to write sentence 26?

F.Choice: In closing, I give you this solemn promise. That if you elect me as president of the sophomore class, I'll give it my all.

G.Choice: In closing, I give you this solemn promise: if you elect me as president of the sophomore class, I'll give it my all.

H.Choice: In closing, to give you this solemn promise: if you elect me as president of the sophomore class, I'll give it my all.

J.Choice: Sentence 26 is written correctly in the paper.

SubTopics: Write an [analytical] essay of sufficient length.
Content: The author uses descriptive examples in paragraph 4 to  —

A.Choice: emphasize that libraries contain many types of books

B.Choice: differentiate between childhood expectations and adult experiences

C.Choice: illustrate the power that books have to expand the imagination

D.Choice: reflect on the ways that libraries have changed over the years

SubTopics: Analyze how literary essays interweave personal examples and ideas with factual information to explain, present a perspective, or describe a situation or event.
Content: The author uses similes at the end of paragraph 3 to highlight  —

F.Choice: that common things can be taken for granted

G.Choice: the various ways that language affects people

H.Choice: the impact of childhood memories on learning

J.Choice: how children's books affected the author

SubTopics: Analyze how literary essays interweave personal examples and ideas with factual information to explain, present a perspective, or describe a situation or event.
Content: How does paragraph 6 contribute to the author's message?

A.Choice: It presents his argument for replacing libraries with modern technology.

B.Choice: It offers a solution to the problem of books becoming outdated.

C.Choice: It details the advantages of books to support his belief about their value.

D.Choice: It explores whether the best source of knowledge is the Internet or libraries.

SubTopics: Analyze the influence of mythic, classical and traditional literature on 20th and 21st century literature.
Content: What is the author's tone in this essay?

F.Choice: Determined

G.Choice: Passionate

H.Choice: Remorseful

J.Choice: Humorous

SubTopics: Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about the varied structural patterns and features of literary nonfiction and provide evidence from text to support their understanding.
Content: Paragraph 7 highlights the author's message by suggesting that books  —

A.Choice: will eventually be replaced by other media

B.Choice: offer something deeper than other forms of entertainment

C.Choice: are more appealing to people with academic backgrounds

D.Choice: provide people with knowledge not available elsewhere

SubTopics: Analyze the influence of mythic, classical and traditional literature on 20th and 21st century literature.
Content: Which word from paragraph 7 is closest in meaning to “weak”?

F.Choice: subtle

G.Choice: impenetrable

H.Choice: sustained

J.Choice: vulnerable

SubTopics: Analyze textual context (within a sentence and in larger sections of text) to distinguish between the denotative and connotative meanings of words.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 5.

:box:A library is a storehouse, preserving what humans have learned, generation by generation, in every land, but it is a storehouse with doors and windows and hallways opening outward to the vast, sprawling, worldwide treasure trove of human knowledge.
The author uses a metaphor in this sentence to  —

A.Choice: describe the welcoming architecture and practical layout of libraries

B.Choice: highlight the way libraries continually update their collections

C.Choice: emphasize the role libraries play in collecting and sharing information

D.Choice: show the way libraries encourage patrons to learn in different ways

SubTopics: Analyze how literary essays interweave personal examples and ideas with factual information to explain, present a perspective, or describe a situation or event.
Content: In paragraph 12, people who act in altruistic ways are  —

F.Choice: selfless

G.Choice: persistent

H.Choice: resourceful

J.Choice: dignified

SubTopics: Analyze textual context (within a sentence and in larger sections of text) to distinguish between the denotative and connotative meanings of words.
Content: By discussing the various people who use Little Free Libraries, the author  —

A.Choice: emphasizes the international appeal of Little Free Libraries

B.Choice: presents opinions that contradict her own

C.Choice: provides support from researchers who have studied Little Free Libraries

D.Choice: clarifies the meanings of terms she uses

SubTopics: Make subtle inferences and draw complex conclusions about the ideas in text and their organizational patterns.
Content: In cultures around the world, the Little Free Libraries are  —

F.Choice: replacing brick-and-mortar libraries

G.Choice: influencing people in positive ways

H.Choice: stocked with books from large libraries

J.Choice: supported by local governments

SubTopics: Make subtle inferences and draw complex conclusions about the ideas in text and their organizational patterns.
Content: From paragraph 14, the reader can infer that the author  —

A.Choice: enjoys reading books by international authors

B.Choice: appreciates the opportunity for discovery provided by Little Free Libraries

C.Choice: thinks e-books fail to offer the same variety of topics as printed books do

D.Choice: understands the limitations of Little Free Libraries

SubTopics: Make subtle inferences and draw complex conclusions about the ideas in text and their organizational patterns.
Content: Which sentence best states the main idea of the selection?

F.Choice: Building Little Free Libraries was appealing to DooSun You of South Korea because books are a treasure in his life that he wanted to share with his neighbors.

G.Choice: Hundreds of Little Free Libraries have been built with funds collected by people who have started fundraising campaigns on the Internet.

H.Choice: Little Free Libraries are growing in popularity around the world because they bring neighbors together and make books more accessible.

J.Choice: Little Free Libraries are small wooden boxes that hold a wide variety of books that appeal to many different types of people.

SubTopics: Explain the controlling idea and specific purpose of an expository text and distinguish the most important from the less important details that support the author's purpose.
Content: The author uses parentheses in paragraphs 10 and 14 to  —

A.Choice: simplify difficult concepts in the article

B.Choice: insert her own asides into the article

C.Choice: provide a counterargument to the article

D.Choice: add credibility to the article

SubTopics: Make subtle inferences and draw complex conclusions about the ideas in text and their organizational patterns.
Content: Use the map below to answer the question.
problems/TX17HSE1/media/32a.jpg
Which inference about Little Free Libraries from the article does the map support?

F.Choice: They provide low-tech entertainment.

G.Choice: They appeal primarily to children.

H.Choice: They benefit local communities.

J.Choice: They offer an unusual selection of books.

SubTopics: Analyze factual, quantitative, or technical data presented in multiple graphical sources.
Content: The author organizes the selection by  —

A.Choice: presenting individual experiences from people around the world to provide a positive account of Little Free Libraries

B.Choice: comparing Little Free Libraries to brick-and-mortar libraries

C.Choice: providing a chronological account of the development of Little Free Libraries

D.Choice: discussing the advantages and disadvantages of building Little Free Libraries in areas that have experienced natural disasters

SubTopics: Make subtle inferences and draw complex conclusions about the ideas in text and their organizational patterns.
Content: Read these quotations from the two selections.

:box:Hᴜɴɢᴇʀ ꜰᴏʀ Bᴏᴏᴋs

It [the author's childhood library] seemed enormous to me because, week by week, year by year, I passed through those library doors into the great world of human thought and art and story.

:box:Tʜᴇ Lᴏᴡ-Tᴇᴄʜ Aᴘᴘᴇᴀʟ ᴏꜰ Lɪᴛᴛʟᴇ Fʀᴇᴇ Lɪʙʀᴀʀɪᴇs

A girl walking home from school might pick up a graphic novel that gets her excited about reading; a man on his way to the bus stop might find a volume of poetry that changes his outlook on life.
Both of these quotations support the idea that people value  —

F.Choice: communities that welcome diversity

G.Choice: the chance to share experiences with others

H.Choice: making the world a better place

J.Choice: the opportunity to learn something new

SubTopics: Spell correctly, including using various resources to determine and check correct spellings.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 2 of “Hunger for Books.”

:box:At that moment, standing in the children's room of the library in Ravenna, Ohio, I realized that if there were still people writing such fresh and fragrant books, then maybe one day I could write some as well.
Which quotation from “The Low-Tech Appeal of Little Free Libraries” expresses a similar sentiment?

A.Choice: When he saw the people of his community gathering around it like a neighborhood water cooler, exchanging conversation as well as books, he knew he wanted to take his simple idea farther.

B.Choice: But as DooSun You scrolled through the results, an appealingly anti-tech concept popped up.

C.Choice: “Little Free Libraries create neighborhood heroes,” says Bol.

D.Choice: When you open the door, serendipity (and your neighbors' taste) dictates what you'll find.

SubTopics: Spell correctly, including using various resources to determine and check correct spellings.
Content: Both the traditional libraries described in “Hunger for Books” and the Little Free Libraries in the other article are described as  —

F.Choice: havens for people who do not like modern technology

G.Choice: repositories of knowledge that offer opportunities for discovery

H.Choice: popular local meeting places where people work together

J.Choice: places that are inexpensive to establish and operate

SubTopics: Spell correctly, including using various resources to determine and check correct spellings.
Content: Which quotation from “The Low-Tech Appeal of Little Free Libraries” best supports the message of “Hunger for Books”?

A.Choice: In some places, Little Free Libraries are filling a role usually served by brick-and-mortar libraries; the organization's Books Around the Block program, for example, aims to bring LFLs to places where kids and adults don't have easy access to books.

B.Choice: “I hoped to share that feeling with my neighbors — that's the reason I wanted a Little Free Library.”

C.Choice: “We have a natural sense of wanting to be connected, but there are so many things that push us apart,” Bol says. “I think Little Free Libraries open the door to conversations we want to have with each other.”

D.Choice: “Reading books is one of the most valuable things in my life. I think a book is equal to a treasure,” he says.

SubTopics: Spell correctly, including using various resources to determine and check correct spellings.
Content: While “Hunger for Books” emphasizes the personal experience of reading, “The Low-Tech Appeal of Little Free Libraries”  —

F.Choice: presents the perspectives of librarians and reading specialists

G.Choice: depicts reading as an activity that is difficult but rewarding

H.Choice: suggests that reading is an activity that unites entire communities

J.Choice: reveals the differences in reading preferences around the world

SubTopics: Spell correctly, including using various resources to determine and check correct spellings.
Content: Which word from the selection means “supporting” or “recommending”?

A.Choice: browsing (paragraph 5)

B.Choice: lingering (paragraph 11)

C.Choice: bemoaning (paragraph 16)

D.Choice: advocating (paragraph 16)

SubTopics: Analyze textual context (within a sentence and in larger sections of text) to distinguish between the denotative and connotative meanings of words.
Content: What evidence does the author provide to support the claims he makes in paragraphs 5 through 7?

F.Choice: Personal anecdotes and opinions of experts who have studied the Internet

G.Choice: Scientific studies and statistics about Internet use

H.Choice: Historical facts regarding the effects of television and the Internet

J.Choice: Results of opinion polls about Internet use

SubTopics: Analyze the relevance, quality, and credibility of evidence given to support or oppose an argument for a specific audience.
Content: Why is a cartoon an effective accompaniment to the selection?

A.Choice: In the selection, the author notes that the news is always bad.

B.Choice: The author maintains a lighthearted tone throughout the selection.

C.Choice: In the selection, the author stresses the importance of preventing boredom.

D.Choice: The author focuses on the rewards of creativity throughout the selection.

SubTopics: Students use comprehension skills to analyze how words, images, graphics, and sounds work together in various forms to impact meaning.
Content: In paragraph 11, the author uses personification to show that the computer  —

F.Choice: has the power to tempt him

G.Choice: is capable of evil

H.Choice: deserves his sympathy

J.Choice: has its own vulnerabilities

SubTopics: Analyze famous speeches for the rhetorical structures and devices used to convince the reader of the authors' propositions.
Content: Which quotation best supports the main idea of the selection?

A.Choice: The demon iPad beckoned silently from the picnic table.

B.Choice: For several years, I kept my Internet addiction under control by using inconvenient technology: a creaky laptop and a slow dial-up connection.

C.Choice: It's important not to let the convenience of the Internet get in the way of simpler beauties.

D.Choice: I love having the world's newspapers on my electronic doorstep.

SubTopics: Explain the controlling idea and specific purpose of an expository text and distinguish the most important from the less important details that support the author's purpose.
Content: The author's position about the Internet is that  —

F.Choice: people should not rely solely on the Internet to provide them with news and other information

G.Choice: although the Internet is often useful, it can become addictive and hamper human interaction

H.Choice: people can have meaningful vacations only if they leave all electronic devices at home

J.Choice: even though there are some good things about the Internet, overall it has affected civilization for the worse

SubTopics: Analyze famous speeches for the rhetorical structures and devices used to convince the reader of the authors' propositions.
Content: In the article, paragraph 15 functions as  —

A.Choice: evidence to support a point made in paragraph 13

B.Choice: a personal anecdote that illustrates an idea in paragraph 14

C.Choice: a restatement of the author's main argument

D.Choice: historical context to allow the reader to understand the article's setting

SubTopics: Analyze the relevance, quality, and credibility of evidence given to support or oppose an argument for a specific audience.
Content: The story is told from the perspective of  —

F.Choice: a third-person narrator who is not fully trustworthy

G.Choice: an omniscient third-person narrator

H.Choice: an unreliable first-person narrator

J.Choice: a first-person narrator who is naive

SubTopics: Analyze the way in which a work of fiction is shaped by the narrator's point of view.
Content: Which quotation provides the best evidence that the story takes place in a rural setting?

A.Choice: On one of our walks, she headed for the bushes.

B.Choice: When the first frost came in November, Aunt Jessie fretted.

C.Choice: She reached across the bush in front and touched my plastic rose.

D.Choice: I ran to the barn, ashamed and confused.

SubTopics: Analyze how authors develop complex yet believable characters in works of fiction through a range of literary devices, including character foils.
Content: The dialogue in paragraph 5 reveals  —

F.Choice: Aunt Jessie's cruelty and the narrator's hope for redemption

G.Choice: Aunt Jessie's pragmatism and the narrator's need to gain approval

H.Choice: Aunt Jessie's fatalism and the narrator's desire to console

J.Choice: Aunt Jessie's sarcasm and the narrator's longing for acceptance

SubTopics: Analyze how authors develop complex yet believable characters in works of fiction through a range of literary devices, including character foils.
Content: The description of Aunt Jessie in paragraph 3 emphasizes that she  —

A.Choice: likes to be in control of situations

B.Choice: does not want to admit her difficulty overcoming grief

C.Choice: remains distant from her family

D.Choice: continues to mourn the death of her child

SubTopics: Analyze how authors develop complex yet believable characters in works of fiction through a range of literary devices, including character foils.
Content: Which quotation provides the best evidence of the narrator's sensitivity?

F.Choice: She and I would walk through them, counting the blooms.

G.Choice: It sent a shiver through me.

H.Choice: I snuck it into the rosebushes in the yard, tying it to a branch.

J.Choice: Bonnie and I were wandering around the store, unable to make up our minds what to choose.

SubTopics: Analyze how authors develop complex yet believable characters in works of fiction through a range of literary devices, including character foils.
Content: In paragraph 2, the “first frost” represents the  —

A.Choice: persistence of hope

B.Choice: unfairness of life

C.Choice: inevitability of death

D.Choice: beginning of trouble

SubTopics: Students understand, make inferences and draw conclusions about how an author's sensory language creates imagery in literary text and provide evidence from text to support their understanding.
Content: In comparison to what the other children spend their money on at the store, the narrator's purchase makes her seem  —

F.Choice: unselfish

G.Choice: practical

H.Choice: gullible

J.Choice: romantic

SubTopics: Analyze how authors develop complex yet believable characters in works of fiction through a range of literary devices, including character foils.
Content: Read the information in the box below.

:box:The national publication USA Weekend began sponsoring Make a Difference Day in 1992 in partnership with the HandsOn Network. On the fourth Saturday in October, everyone is encouraged to gather with friends and neighbors to help fill a need in their community. Millions of Americans participate every year.
Working together can be one of the most effective ways to improve the quality of people's lives. Think carefully about this statement.
Write an essay explaining one way that people can work together to make a difference.

:ibox:Be sure to  — 

• clearly state your thesis
• organize and develop your ideas effectively
• choose your words carefully
• edit your writing for grammar, mechanics, and spelling
